title: Marston's reassures investors over living wage
text:

Wed, Jul 22, 2015, 14:58 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 32 mins Marston's reassures investors over living wage By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 14 minutes ago Print 
The boss of the pub company said it had predicted that wages would rise and was prepared for the increase 
The boss of Marston’s has calmed investor fears that the imposition of the national living wage will cause a painful increase in costs by reassuring shareholders that the pub company had already accounted for the new Government policy before it was unveiled. 
Chief executive Ralph Findlay said the business “could see which way the wind has been blowing on the living wage for some time, because local authorities and publicly funded bodies have been calling for the introduction of the living wage in their organisations”. 
The minimum wage for workers aged 25 or over will rise from £6.50 currently to £7.20 next April, and hit £9 by 2020, Chancellor George Osborne revealed in the Budget earlier this month. 
It immediately sparked fears that companies in the leisure, retail and social care industries would be hit by higher costs and forced to cut jobs. It provoked a furious response from JD Wetherspoon founder Tim Martin, who called the increase another “capricious” government initiative that would cause more pub closures. 
However, Mr Findlay said that while the scale of the hike was greater than expected, “much of that change we had already got in our forecasting and in our plans”. 
He added: “We’re probably looking at a cost of something like £1m in 2016 and then a couple of million per year thereafter.” 
Numis analyst Douglas Jack praised Marston’s “sensible approach” to the living wage, and shares in the company, which operates 1,600 pubs and employs about 13,000 people, rose as much as 3.9pc amid investor relief. 
An encouraging trading update also buoyed the stock, with Marston’s posting a 2pc increase in like-for-like sales at its destination and premium pubs in the 10 weeks to July 18 compared with last year, and a similar rise at its taverns business. 
Given most of its pubs have outdoor spaces, the recent fine weather has helped trading, Mr Findlay said. Last year, the company was also hampered by the football World Cup, which “isn’t particularly good for food-led pub businesses”.
